title.rendered: New Logo for Foursquare in Collaboration with Red Antler

content.rendered:
Launched in 2009 at SXSW Interactive (obvs!) as a stand-alone app allowing users to check in at a location and see other users’ location, Foursquare is now a double-threat ecosystem of apps: Swarm, for checking in and the eponymous Foursquare for discovery. Since I am not a Foursquare user I had no idea that this second app, Swarm, existed (since May of this year) and that the main check-in functionality of Foursquare — what made it famous in the first place — was being relocated in order to transform it into a “personalized local search” app. To signal the change to this new two-app model and the new raison d’être of the famed app, Foursquare has introduced a new logo designed in collaboration with Brooklyn, NY-based Red Antler.

Our teams worked hand in hand through every step of the process, from strategy through design, to understand all aspects of Foursquare’s new services and the user interface. And when we say we ‘worked together’, we mean that literally; the Red Antler design team worked onsite at the Foursquare office, and Foursquare designers often spent days in RA’s Dumbo office.

Red Antler blog post

Second, if you build a totally new app, you need a totally new logo. Our logo is changing from the check-in checkmark to something representing the new Foursquare. We designed it to be a mix of map pin and superhero emblem. We’ve always thought of Foursquare as giving you superpowers to explore your city, and our new logo reflects that vision. It’s coming soon to a homescreen near you.

Foursquare blog post

The old wordmark managed to make House Industries’ Neutraface (italic) look like it was the Mayor of Uglyville by wrapping it in an unfortunate stroke and smushing the letters together real good. Meanwhile, the app icon was a giant checkmark merged with a pin — a decent concept to start with but the execution was sloppy and unsophisticated. The new monogram and wordmark correct all of these wrongs.

The all-uppercase wordmark is bold, solid, and contemporary, and I’m loving the “Q”. I particularly enjoy that it’s not another flimsy Humanist sans to make it look more friendly and approachable. The new monogram is cool. It’s immediately clear that it’s both an “F” and a pin, and it could also be interpreted as a speech bubble, which is not a bad thing, since it’s all about the feedback of users on each location. As far as the superhero emblem thinking… yeah, that’s cute but I wouldn’t make a whole PR thing about it.

While the logo change is relevant and has been well done, this is a clear case of Foursquare wanting to establish a fresh beginning, moving away from any remnants of its original identity in order to rally users for its new functionality. The new logo and identity’s true success will depend on whether users embrace the revised namesake app, due next month, and pull double duty with the other app, Swarm. At a time where we are already scrambling to keep up with apps for Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Vine, and even Yelp (a clear competitor in the recommendation/reviews area), it’s a challenging proposition, so all those superpowers the new logo is meant to have will be needed.

PS. Given the recent propensity of the internet to find genitalia in logos I am happy to report that no one has mentioned that the counterspace between the F’s crossbars look like a pink, erect penis. Maybe all the writers at HuffPo and FastCo and Gizmodo and Adweek, et al already met their quota for the year for stories of genitalia logos.
